title: Data Science
text:
I think being a data scientist is about collecting, cleaning, and analyzing data through visualizations.
I think data scientists are more focused on the coding and visualization part of analysis, while statisticians are more concerned with collecting data and performing mathematical analyses.
I am very new to both, but I would say I have more of a background in statistics than data science.



Assigning variable y, the density of the Petal.Width column of the iris table.

y <- density(iris$Petal.Width)

class(y)

[1] "density"

typeof(y)

[1] "list"

str(y)

List of 8
 $ x         : num [1:512] -0.656 -0.648 -0.64 -0.633 -0.625 ...
 $ y         : num [1:512] 0.00161 0.00178 0.00197 0.00217 0.00239 ...
 $ bw        : num 0.252
 $ n         : int 150
 $ old.coords: logi FALSE
 $ call      : language density.default(x = iris$Petal.Width)
 $ data.name : chr "iris$Petal.Width"
 $ has.na    : logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "density"


Creating a plot for variable y.

title: Data Science
text:
Assigning variable y, the density of the Petal.Width column of the iris table.

y <- density(iris$Petal.Width)

class(y)

[1] "density"

typeof(y)

[1] "list"

str(y)

List of 8
 $ x         : num [1:512] -0.656 -0.648 -0.64 -0.633 -0.625 ...
 $ y         : num [1:512] 0.00161 0.00178 0.00197 0.00217 0.00239 ...
 $ bw        : num 0.252
 $ n         : int 150
 $ old.coords: logi FALSE
 $ call      : language density.default(x = iris$Petal.Width)
 $ data.name : chr "iris$Petal.Width"
 $ has.na    : logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "density"


Creating a plot for variable y.

title: test_mkdwn
text:
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00  

print("cars")

[1] "cars"
